headline.main: Cosmetic Saves a Cure for Sleeping Sickness

docs.abstract: Cure for sleeping sickness, disease devastating parts of central Africa, may soon be available cheaply because it has second, profitable use: elimination of facial hair in women; drug, eflornithine, was abandoned by drug companies after early hope that it would help fight cancer was dashed; current shortage is cited by critics of industry who say multinational drug companies ignore the poor; now Bristol-Myers Squibb Co and Gillette Co have introduced eflornithine in facial cream, Vaniqa, and Bristol-Myers is near agreement with World Health Orgn and Doctors Without Borders for companies to make injectable form to treat sleeping sickness; eflornithine is so effective at reviving even comatose patients that it is known as resurrection drug (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A cure for sleeping sickness, a disease devastating parts of central Africa, may soon be available cheaply because it has a second, profitable use: it eliminates facial hair in women. The drug, eflornithine, is so effective at reviving even comatose patients that it is known as the resurrection drug.
